title: SeRA Current & Pending Support | Office of Research Administration

structured_sections.heading: Overview of the SeRA Disclosures/Current and Pending Support Report
structured_sections.content: Anyone with an active SU Net ID can run the Disclosures/Current and Pending Support Report in SeRA. This report is intended as a starting point for preparing official Current and Pending (Other) Support documents and Biosketches for sponsors. It is NOT meant to be submitted as-is. The report gathers all available information from SeRA and provides a central place to manage an investigator's resources. Users should always follow the specific sponsor and solicitation guidance when preparing disclosure documents. The NIH, NSF, and DOD have specific requirements for disclosing foreign funding and talent recruitment programs.

structured_sections.heading: How to Run the Report
structured_sections.content: To run the report, navigate to the 'Reports' section in SeRA's left-hand menu. Click on 'Disclosures Report (Current and Pending Support)'. Search for and select the investigator's name, then click 'Get Report'. The report will be displayed on the screen, broken into 10 sections, and can be exported to PDF or Excel.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 1: OPACS Disclosures
structured_sections.content: This section displays activities the investigator has disclosed in the Outside Professional Activities Certification System (OPACS). This includes Advisory Board Memberships, outside appointments, consulting activities, and in-kind support. Any modifications to this data must be made in OPACS. The report details whether consulting activities involve research, have the potential to impact the investigator's research portfolio, or involve contracts with confidentiality clauses, which is relevant for NSF disclosures.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 2: Sponsored Projects
structured_sections.content: This section lists active awarded projects and pending proposals where the investigator has a role (PI, Co-PI, etc.). It does not include fellowship mentor roles. Users can click 'Details' to see more information like total award amount and effort commitments. From the 'Actions' menu, users can edit Major Goals, reject pending proposals, or add department-managed notes and effort.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 3: Proposals in Development
structured_sections.content: This lists proposals where a PDRF has been started but not yet completed. It is up to the investigator to determine if these need to be included in a disclosure document, based on sponsor guidelines. For example, the NSF requires the proposal being submitted to be listed on its own Current and Pending Support document.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 4: Pre-Proposals
structured_sections.content: This section displays pre-proposals, Letters of Intent (LOIs), and Step 1 Proposals entered in SeRA. These may need to be disclosed as pending projects, depending on sponsor requirements.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 5: Completed Projects
structured_sections.content: This lists sponsored projects that ended within the last 5 years. This information should generally NOT be listed on NIH or NSF support documents unless explicitly required by the sponsor. The effort for completed projects should be listed as 0 person-months.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 6: Research Related Agreements (RRAs)
structured_sections.content: This section shows agreements like Data Use Agreements (DUAs) and Material Transfer Agreements (MTAs). The agreement itself may not need to be disclosed, but if it provides in-kind resources (e.g., materials not freely available), those resources may require disclosure based on sponsor rules.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 7: Department Research Awards
structured_sections.content: This is a section for manually entered data about research awards funded through gift accounts or PTAs. This information is not pulled from other Stanford systems and should be reported in the Projects and Proposals section of disclosure documents.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 8: In-Kind Contributions
structured_sections.content: This section allows for the manual entry and management of in-kind resources available to an investigator. This data is not validated against other Stanford systems. Sponsor definitions of what constitutes a disclosable in-kind contribution vary (e.g., NSF requires an associated time commitment, while NIH does not for high-value materials).

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 9: Overlap
structured_sections.content: This section is for manually entering and managing information about scientific, budgetary, or effort overlap between projects, proposals, and resources. Sponsor requirements for disclosing overlap differ; for instance, the NSF requires an overlap statement for every item, even if it's 'N/A', while the NIH requires a summary of potential overlap for the entire portfolio.

structured_sections.heading: Report Section 10: External International Agreements (EIA)
structured_sections.content: The NIH requires institutions to submit copies of agreements related to foreign appointments or employment. These EIAs are submitted and reviewed in OPACS. This section of the SeRA report indicates if an investigator has uploaded any such agreements. The details can be viewed on the investigator's 'My Projects' page in SeRA. These agreements must be approved in OPACS before being included in an NIH Other Support submission.
